Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Turbulent Dissipation and Plasma Heating in the Near-Earth Solar Wind
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the Principal Investigator (PI) will exploit his established research program in numerical plasma gyrokinetics, specifically tailored for the comprehensive study of solar wind turbulence. His existing numerical simulations require advanced High Performance Computing (HPC) resources and offer a unique capability to answer fundamental and compelling questions about the nature of kinetic turbulence in the solar wind, the physical mechanisms responsible for its dissipation, and the resulting plasma heating. This project will focus on several key physics questions, including identifying the processes occurring in the solar wind that lead to its observed turbulent energy spectra, determining which physical mechanisms are responsible for dissipating solar wind turbulence, how the energy of turbulent fluctuations heats solar wind plasma, and how energy is partitioned among among the protons, electrons, and minority ion species in the solar wind.

The PI's education and training program includes a plan to develop a workforce with the experience and ability to effectively use HPC resources in space plasma physics, as well as in other fields of scientific research and technology development. The PI will establish the "Iowa High Performance Computing Summer School" to offer a hands-on, project-based course to 80 graduate students over 5 years, allowing them to integrate HPC approaches into their own research efforts. By providing this next generation of scientists with a solid foundation in parallel algorithm design and supercomputing skills, the PI's educational program will contribute to sustaining a technologically competitive workforce in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project supported research into the fundamental nature of turbulence in space and astrophysical plasmas. Turbulence mediates the transfer of energy from large-scale plasma flows and magnetic fields down to the small scales at which the energy of those turbulent motions is ultimately converted into heat of the plasma ions and electrons. Developing a detailed understanding of the energy transfer and plasma heating due to turbulence will enable us to answer longstanding questions in space physics, such as how the solar corona is heated to millions of degrees Kelvin, and to interpret better our observations of distant astrophysical systems, such as the accretion disk surrounding the supermassive black hole at the center of the Galaxy.

This award made possible four major achievements in improving our understanding of space and astrophysical plasma turbulence.  First, we performed kinetic simulations over the entire dissipation range of plasma turbulence from the ion to the electron scales, reproducing for the first time the energy spectrum observed in spacecraft observations of solar wind turbulence. These results support the model that plasma turbulence is fundamentally dominated by a sea of nonlinear interacting Alfven waves.  Second, we demonstrate that it is the nonlinear interactions among Alfven waves traveling up and down the interplanetary magnetic field—commonly denoted Alfven wave collisions—that govern the cascade of turbulent energy to smaller scales.  Third, we discovered that Alfven wave collisions in the strongly nonlinear limit naturally generate current sheets, providing a first-principles explanation for the observation of current sheets that are ubiquitously found in both spacecraft measurements and numerical simulations of plasma turbulence.  Fourth, based on the equations of nonlinear kinetic plasma theory, we developed the field-particle correlation technique, an innovative method for distinguishing the physical mechanisms responsible for the energization of particles and plasma heating in turbulent plasmas.  A key feature of this new technique is that it can be applied using measurements from single spacecraft missions, providing a concrete strategy for definitively answering major open questions in space physics—such as the heating of the solar corona—using observations from current and upcoming NASA missions, including the Magnetospheric Multiscale and Parker Solar Probe missions.  Initial application of the field-particle correlation technique to kinetic simulations of strong plasma turbulence have shown definitively that Landau damping—a collisionless interaction between waves and particles, where ions and electrons gain energy from passing waves in the electric field, somewhat akin to a surfer catching an incoming ocean wave—indeed plays an important role in the energization of ions and electrons.

Together, the scientific accomplishments of this project establish Alfven wave collisions as a fundamental building block of plasma turbulence and open a specific path to determining definitively the physical mechanisms of particle energization and plasma heating in space and astrophysical plasmas.

Beyond the scientific accomplishments of this project, which may impact a wide range of fields from space physics and astrophysics to the fusion energy program due to the omnipresence of plasma turbulence in those systems, the educational component of this CAREER project has broadly impacted graduate education and human resource development in STEM fields. This award supported five years of the Iowa High Performance Computing Summer School, training a total of 80 graduate students across a wide range of fields---from science and engineering to business and medicine---in the skills of high-performance computing. A technical workforce trained in high-performance computing is essential to maintaining our nation's global leadership in science and technology.
